Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resilient Decentralized Estimation and Control for Cooperative Rigid Body Multivehicle Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research program will significantly advance autonomous navigation and control capabilities for cooperative multivehicle systems, by incorporating realistic vehicle and communication models, and resilient decentralized estimation and control strategies. The results will be applicable, for example, to swarms of micro air vehicles and formations of spacecraft. Powerful analytic techniques exist to control individual vehicles, to represent the interactions of networked systems, to accommodate communication delays, and to account for uncertainty. This project will address the substantial technical obstacles that stand in the way of integrating these various results in a unified framework. The ability to exploit large numbers of interconnected vehicles to perform practical operations is increasingly useful -- even necessary -- in applications including exploration, search and rescue, agriculture, weather monitoring, surveillance, satellite geodesy, and environmental monitoring. Integrated educational efforts include demonstrations to high school students of robotic vehicles and multi-agent network control simulations.

Current approaches to multi-vehicle estimation and control designs invoke strong simplifying assumptions, such as modeling individual vehicle dynamics by a point mass or by a single- or double-integrator; assuming that all vehicles have identical dynamics and uncertainty characterization; and neglecting communication delays, or assuming that they are known or constant. The resulting idealized controllers have limited functionality under real-world conditions. This project strives to overcome these limitations by using diverse techniques from robust, nonlinear, and hybrid control theory, graph theory, and geometric mechanics. The multivehicle system is described by a unique, global, and singularity-free representation, as a network of heterogeneous rigid bodies evolving on separate copies of the special Euclidean group SE(3) -- that is, on the space of rigid translations and rotations in three dimensions. The inter-vehicle communication topology is specified by a time-varying graph with heterogeneous, connection-dependent time delay. Global, robust and resilient estimation and control schemes will be based on a Lyapunov-Morse-Krasovskii functional approach, and implemented using decentralized algorithms, that is, each vehicle will require only local information to compute its control action. The results will be validated with laboratory-scale experiments, and will advance the system-theoretical foundations of decentralized estimation and control, and enable more capable, robust, and autonomous multi-vehicle systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on the development and testing of new advanced algorithms for the autonomous navigation and control of cooperative multivehicle systems (MVSs), such as formations or swarms of unmanned air or space vehicles, using realistic rigid body vehicle models and improved strategies in resilient decentralized estimation and control (DEC). Cooperative MVS missions are becoming increasingly useful and often necessary in both civilian and military applications including exploration, disaster response, search and rescue, agriculture, gathering data from safety-critical environments, weather monitoring, surveillance, satellite geodesy, climate change research, and space-based missions, among others.  Many current DEC strategies use over-simplified models, assume ideal conditions (e.g. no heterogeneity in dynamics and uncertainties), and/or do not account for communication delays, thus limiting multivehicle system functionality in real-world conditions. To overcome these limitations, in this project diverse techniques have been employed from robust, nonlinear, fractional, and hybrid control theory to advance the system-theoretical foundations of DEC.  Specifically, by accounting for realistic vehicle models, including the vehicle’s attitude (orientation or pointing direction), and using control techniques that account for uncertainties associated with the vehicles and their environment as well as time delays associated with the communication pathways between neighboring vehicles, the ability to exploit large numbers of these interconnected vehicles to perform practical operations is enabled. This completed research project has established a methodological foundation for advanced DEC strategies with direct connection to many MVS applications including swarms of micro air vehicles and spacecraft formations.  In addition, the project also aids other applications of complex systems, such as energy, power, and process control systems, which exchange matter, energy, or information.  The chief advancements in MVS technology addressed in this project have included 1) blending a global unique and singularity-free representation of rigid body motion with a graph-theoretic representation of MVSs and their communication topology; 2) designing DEC schemes that are globally valid, achieve resilient performance in the presence of a broad spectrum of uncertainties, vehicle complexity and heterogeneity, and communication time delays; 3) characterizing time-varying communication topologies to achieve given MVS cooperation tasks and the dependence of time delays on the system’s connectivity; and 4) evaluating the proposed concepts and algorithms in limited laboratory-level experiments.  The resulting resilient DEC strategies enable more capable, robust, and truly autonomous MVSs and create new investigative tools that can be applied to disparate applications of MVSs and networked systems where complex interdependencies are important. While these advancements lie chiefly within the domains of guidance, control and navigation (and the results have been disseminated in journals and at conferences associated with these disciplines), they have also been applied in a study on spacecraft formation flying in low Earth orbit which was presented at a professional conference in Aug. 2019. 

 

The research funding associated with this NSF project has enabled three Ph.D. students and one M.S. student to carry out investigations toward the completion of their graduate degrees and present their work at several professional conferences. It has also enabled these students to receive cross-training in the form of Skype seminars with the principal colleague in this collaborative project as well as travel to his university to participate in his research group activities.  The PI has given several invited talks on material related to this project in various UA departments, other universities, a national laboratory, and through outreach at local schools.  Furthermore, the PI and one of his graduate students participated in the Air Force Research Laboratory Faculty Fellowship Program in which the results from this project were applied to practical problems of interest to the Air Force in a spin-off research collaboration which is still active, as well as in a SBIR project with a small business in the defense sector.
